name: EIRA v1.0.0
documentation:
This  file provides the ArchiMate model of the European Interoperability Reference Architecture (EIRA). The EIRA has been developed in the context of Action 2.1 of the Interoperability Solutions for European Public Administrations (ISA) Programme. The EIRA is a reference architecture focused on the interoperability of digital public services. It is composed of the most important architecture building blocks needed to promote cross-border and cross-sector interactions between public administrations. It is based on the Service Oriented Architecture style and uses ArchiMate as a modelling notation. The EIRA implements the European Interoperability Framework (EIF) . 

The latest release of the EIRA is available on Joinup: https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/asset/eia/description

elements.name: Data Policy
Specification
elements.documentation:
A Specification is  a document that states requirements. A specification can be related to activities (e.g. procedure document, process specification and test specification), or products  (e.g. product specification, performance specification and drawing). [ISO 9000:2005] 

Source : https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:std:iso:9000:ed-3:v1:en:term:3.7.3

elements.name: Semantic Interoperability Specification
elements.documentation: A Semantic Interoperability Specification defines a necessary attribute that shall be fully met to support semantic interoperability.

elements.name: Legal Interoperability Specification
elements.documentation: A Legal Interoperability Specification defines a necessary attribute that shall be fully met to support legal interoperability in the Public Policy Cycle.

elements.name: Organisational Interoperability Specification
elements.documentation: An Organisational Interoperability Specification defines a necessary attribute that shall be fully met to support organisational interoperability.

elements.name: Interoperability Specification
elements.documentation: An Interoperability Specification is a document  containing agreed  normative statements for solution building blocks used in an information exchange context.  It  can refer to existing  standards or  specifications.

elements.name: Technical Interoperability Specification
elements.documentation: A Technical Interoperability Specifications defines a necessary attribute that shall be fully met to support technical interoperability.

elements.name: Interoperability Strategy
elements.documentation: An Interoperability Strategy is a long term plan addressing interoperability strategic objectives. Example is the European Interoperability Strategy at European level.

elements.name: Organisational Skill
elements.documentation: A set of skills and competencies that, being developed and applied, allow the organisation to perform a certain role in an excellent way (González-Cruz et al. 2009).

elements.name: Organisational Structure
elements.documentation:
An Organisational Structure is the pattern of the distribution of work, flow of communications and instructions in the organisation required to fulfil the organisational objectives.
The way an organisation is set up: 
- matrix-organisation? 
- central/federated model?

[Jayantee Saha - 2006 Management and Organizational Behaviour]

elements.name: Public Administration
elements.documentation: A Public Administration is an organisational entity that provides and/or consumes Public Services.

elements.name: Interoperability Agreement
elements.documentation:
An Interoperability Agreement is the means through which organisations (public administrations, or businesses) formalises the cooperation with one another. These agreements aim at the development of interoperability solutions, which meets the functional / technical requirements and needs of one another. [European Interoperability Framework]

The agreement should include purposes and goals, terms and conditions, governance, and the description of the channel(s).

The EIRA differentiates the following Interoperability Agreements:
- Interoperability Service Agreement (between Public Service Consumers and Public Service Providers;
- Interoperability Collaboration Agreement (between Organisations); or
- Interoperability Provider Agreement (between Public Service Providers).

elements.name: Organisational Interoperability Enabler
elements.documentation: An Organisational Interoperability Enabler consists of elements which describe the functions, principles, rules, and policies in an organisation. These enablers act as sources for the business rules of an organisation.

elements.name: Interoperability Governance
elements.documentation: Interoperability Governance is an organisational procedures for the governance of interoperability usually under the mandate/approach of a public policy. Examples are the comitology procedures for ISA at European level.

elements.name: Public Service Delivery Agent
elements.documentation: A Public Service Delivery Agent delivers a public service on behalf of a Service Providers. An example of this would be pharmacies that deliver a service 'on the behalf of' the Ministry of Health. In this case the pharmacies would be captured as a Service Delivery Agent whereas the Service Provider would be the Ministry of Health.

elements.name: Organisation
elements.documentation: An Organisation is an entity that provides and/or consumes Public Services.

elements.name: Organisational Policy
elements.documentation:
An Organisational Policy defines a set of principles, rules, and guidelines in an organisation. [source: European Interoperability Framework 
http://ec.europa.eu/isa/documents/isa_annex_ii_eif_en.pdf]

elements.name: Citizen
elements.documentation: A Citizens is a consumers of Public Services

elements.name: Public Service
elements.documentation:
A Public Service is an economic activity that public authorities identify as being of particular importance to citizens, businesses and public administrations and that would not be supplied (or would be supplied under different conditions) if there were no public intervention. 

Source: Based on DG Competition
http://ec.europa.eu/competition/state_aid/overview/public_services_en.html

A public service is the capacity to carry out a procedure and exists whether it is used or not. It is a set of deeds and acts performed by or on behalf of a public agency for the benefit of a citizen, a business or another public agency. 
https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/site/core_public_service/rdfs.html#PublicService

A Public Service is considered also based on the commitment to provide it by its provider, regardless of whether or not it is actively being offered.

elements.name: Business Information Exchange
elements.documentation:
A Business Information Exchange is an interaction between two or more public administrations, businesses or citizens.

Source: Based on UN/CEFACT Modelling Methodology (UMM)
http://www.unece.org/cefact/umm/umm_index.html

elements.name: Interoperability Framework
elements.documentation: An Interoperability Framework is a set of interoperability principles, rules, and guidelines in an organisation. Examples are EIF at European level and National schemas of IOP at national level.

elements.name: Public Service Provider
elements.documentation:
A Public Service Provider is a Public Administration or Business providing Public Services financed through public resource. [DG Competition]

Source: 
http://ec.europa.eu/competition/state_aid/overview/public_services_en.html

elements.name: Business Capability
elements.documentation: A Business Capability is the expression or the articulation of the capacity, materials and expertise an organization needs in order to perform core functions. Enterprise architects use business capabilities to illustrate the over-arching needs of the business in order to better strategize IT solutions that meet those business needs.

elements.name: Business Rule
elements.documentation:
A Business Rule is a statement that defines or constrains some aspect of the business.  It is intended to assert business structure, or to control or influence the behaviour of the business.

Source: Business Rules Group; http://www.businessrulesgroup.org/defnbrg.shtml

elements.name: Interoperability Organisational Authority
elements.documentation: An Interoperability Organisational Authority is an organisation holding the responsibility for interoperability governance under the mandate/approach of a Public Policy. Examples are ISA at European level and CIO at national level.

elements.name: Business
elements.documentation: A Business is an organisational entity that provides and/or consumes Public Services. This includes non-governmental organisations and not-for-profit organisations.  [European Interoperability Framework]

elements.name: Service Delivery Model
elements.documentation:
A Service Delivery Model defines how the organisation arranges the delivery of its services to service consumers. This includes:
- How will the service be delivered (e.g. multi-channel, SPOCs, only once)?
- How will the interaction between the service provider and service consumer take place?
- How will certain situations be handled (e.g. incident management)?
- How will the support & maintenance look like? [ITIL v3]

Source: http://www.itil-officialsite.com/

elements.name: Interoperability Skill
elements.documentation: A set of skills and competencies that, being developed and applied, allow the organisation to achieve excellent results in the field of Interoperability (adapted from González-Cruz et al. 2009).

elements.name: Public Service Consumer
elements.documentation:
A Public Service Consumer is a Public Administration, Business or Citizen consuming public services. [European Interoperability Framework]

Source: Based on EIF 2.0
http://ec.europa.eu/isa/documents/isa_annex_ii_eif_en.pdf

elements.name: Organisational Procedure
elements.documentation: An Organisational Procedure is a step-by-step description of the tasks required to support and carry out organizational policies.

elements.name: Business Information
elements.documentation: Business Information is a piece of business data or a group of pieces of business data with a unique business semantics definition in a specific business context [source: ISO15000-5, UN/CEFACT CCTS].

elements.name: Public Service Catalogue
elements.documentation: A Public Service Catalogue is a repository, with information on all public services. It represents the collection of the offered public services. [ITIL v3]

elements.name: Legal Requirement or Constraint
elements.documentation: A Legal Requirement or Constraint is a legal text that mandates and/or guides the creation of an Interoperable European Solution.

elements.name: Public Policy Evaluation
elements.documentation:
A Public Policy Evaluation is an assessment of how the public policy met its objectives (according to defined criteria).

Source: Based on the concepts laid out in http://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/etudes/join/2013/507457/IPOL-IMCO_ET(2013)507457_EN.pdf

elements.name: Public Policy
elements.documentation: A Public Policy is the whole of actions under a policy domain taken by a public authority to bring about social change in the medium and long term. It is based on certain values and objectives and is implemented using a variety of methods. It applies on the territory within which the authority is authorised to act. [Source: EuroVoc,  http://eurovoc.europa.eu/drupal/?q=request&concepturi=http%3A%2F%2Feurovoc.europa.eu%2F8466&termuri=http%3A%2F%2Feurovoc.europa.eu%2F209598&language=en&view=pt&ifacelang=en ].

elements.name: Public Policy Formulation and Implementation Instrument
elements.documentation: A Public Policy Formulation and Implementation Instrument is an instrument that support the formulation and implementation of the policy.

elements.name: Public Policy Implementation
elements.documentation: A Public Policy Implementation is the process of putting a public policy into effect. [Oxford Dictionary]

elements.name: Non-binding Instrument
elements.documentation:
A Non-binding Instrument is a set of recommendations and opinions, as well as rules governing how EU institutions and programmes work, etc. 

Source: http://europa.eu/legislation_summaries/glossary/community_legal_instruments_en.htm

elements.name: Definition of Public Policy Objectives
elements.documentation:
A Definition of Public Policy Objectives is a stage where public policy objectives are defined.

Source: Based on the concepts laid out in http://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/etudes/join/2013/507457/IPOL-IMCO_ET(2013)507457_EN.pdf

elements.name: Legislation Catalogue
elements.documentation: A Legislation Catalogue is a set of legal documents.

elements.name: Public Policy Development Mandate
elements.documentation: A Public Policy Development Mandate is the capacity and authority to carry out tasks within a specific policy domain. [European Interoperability Strategy]

elements.name: Operational Enabler
elements.documentation:
An Operational Enabler is an organisation, person, object or event that makes it possible to implement the policy. [Oxford Dictionary]

Source: http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/enabler

elements.name: Impact Assessment
elements.documentation:
An Impact assessment is a key tool to ensure that the public policy process is carried out on the basis of transparent, comprehensive and balanced evidence, an Impact assessment is an aid to political decision-making.

Source: Based on the concepts laid out in  http://ec.europa.eu/smart-regulation/impact/commission_guidelines/docs/iag_2009_en.pdf

elements.name: Formulation of Public Policy Scenarios
elements.documentation:
A Formulation of Public Policy Scenarios is a stage where a number of public policy options for addressing the problem and achieving the public policy objectives are developed.

Source: Based on the concepts laid out in http://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/etudes/join/2013/507457/IPOL-IMCO_ET(2013)507457_EN.pdf

elements.name: Public Policy Development Enabler
elements.documentation:
A Public Policy Development Enabler is an organisation or thing that make the development and implementation of the Public Policy possible. [Oxford Dictionary]

Source: http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/enabler

elements.name: Public Policy Cycle
elements.documentation:
A Public Policy Cycle is a cycle of stages in the creation and execution of a public policy.

Source: Based on the concepts laid out in section 2.2 of http://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/etudes/join/2013/507457/IPOL-IMCO_ET(2013)507457_EN.pdf

elements.name: Financial Resource
elements.documentation: A Financial Resource is money in the form of cash, securities, creditors, loan facilities, etc.

elements.name: Public Policy Development Approach
elements.documentation: A Public Policy Development Approach is the delegation model used to enforce the policy (centralised vs. decentralised). [European Interoperability Strategy]

elements.name: Implementing Guideline
elements.documentation: An Implementing Guideline is a set of instructions that provides insight into how to implement a policy.

elements.name: Binding Instrument
elements.documentation:
A Binding Instrument is a legal instrument that expresses something which is obligatory.

Source: 
Based on the concepts laid out in http://europa.eu/legislation_summaries/glossary/community_legal_instruments_en.htm

elements.name: Master Data
elements.documentation: Master Data is the authoritative, most accurate data that is available about key business entities, used to establish the context for business transactions and transactional data [source: DAMA DM_BOK, http://www.dama.org].

elements.name: Schema-level Mapping
elements.documentation: A Schema-level Mapping is a mapping between related classes and properties [source: ISO/DIS 25964-2].

elements.name: Data Model
elements.documentation: A Data Model includes formal data names, comprehensive data definitions, proper data structures and precise data integrity rules  [source: DAMA DM_BOK, http://www.dama.org].

elements.name: Syntax Encoding Scheme
elements.documentation: A Syntax Encoding Scheme indicates that the value is a string formatted in accordance with a formal notation [DCMI Glossary], such as ‘2000-01-01’ as the standard expression of a date. Another example is CSV [Source: http://wiki.dublincore.org/index.php/Glossary/Encoding_Scheme].

elements.name: Identifier Scheme
elements.documentation: An Identifier Schema defines the values of an identifier  [source: CEN BII http://spec.cenbii.eu/].

elements.name: Data Set Catalogue
elements.documentation:
A Data Set Catalogue is a curated collection of datasets [source: W3C, 
http://www.w3.org/TR/vocab-dcat/#class-catalog].

elements.name: Character Encoding Scheme
elements.documentation: A Character Encoding Scheme reflects the way a chosen character set is mapped to bytes for manipulation in a computer [W3C]. An example is the UTF-8 standard.

elements.name: Data Set
elements.documentation:
A Data Set is a collection of data, published or curated by a single agent, and available for access or download in one or more formats [source: W3C, 
http://www.w3.org/TR/vocab-dcat/#class-dataset].

elements.name: Core Data Model
elements.documentation: A context-neutral data model that captures the fundamental characteristics of an entity [Source: Core Vocabularies Handbook, https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/site/core_vocabularies/Core_Vocabularies_user_handbook/ ].

elements.name: Representation
elements.documentation: A Representation is a physical embodiment or manifestation of data [based on the Functional Requirements for Bibliographic Records]. It is the perceptible form of information carried by a business object [based on ArchiMate].

elements.name: Transactional Data
elements.documentation: Transactional Data is data that covers the business information related to business transactions and information exchanges [source: based on DAMA DM_BOK, http://www.dama.org].

elements.name: Descriptive Metadata
elements.documentation:
Descriptive metadata describes a resource for purposes such as discovery and identification. It can include elements such as title, abstract, author, and keywords.

Source: 
http://www.niso.org/publications/press/UnderstandingMetadata.pdf

elements.name: Data Standard Catalogue
elements.documentation: A Data Standard Catalogue is a catalogue of Data Standards.

elements.name: Data Standard
elements.documentation: A data standard is a structural metadata specification that describes or defines other data [ISO111179]. Structural metadata indicates how compound objects are put together [NISO]. It can consist of among others data models, reference data, and identifier schemas.

elements.name: Data
elements.documentation: Data is facts represented as text, numbers, graphics, images, sound, or video. Data is the raw material used to represent information, or from which information can be derived [source: DAMA DM_BOK, http://www.dama.org].

elements.name: Data Entity
elements.documentation: A classification of objects found in the real world described by the Noun part of speech – persons, places, things, concepts, and events – of interest to the enterprise  [source: DAMA DM_BOK, http://www.dama.org].

elements.name: Data-level Mapping
elements.documentation: A Data-level Mapping is a mapping between specific data elements (or data values) [source: ISO/DIS 25964-2].

elements.name: Reference Data
elements.documentation:
Reference Data is any data used to organise or categorise other data, or for relating data to information both within and beyond the boundaries of the enterprise. Usually consists of codes and descriptions or definitions [source: DAMA DM_BOK, http://www.dama.org].

Reference data consists typically of a small, discrete set of values that are not updated as part of business transactions but are usually used to impose consistent classiﬁcation. Reference data normally has a low update frequency. Reference data is relevant across more than one business systems belonging to different organisations and sectors [source: J. Jordan & C. Ellen (2009). Business need, data and business intelligence].

elements.name: Trust Registry Service
elements.documentation:
A Trust Registry Service enables the discovery of essential information about e.g. supervised/accredited  trust service providers issuing certificates for electronic signatures, for electronic seals or for website authentication; supervised/accredited  trust services for eSignature, eSeal or TimeStamp creation and validation; supervised/accredited  trust services for eSignature  or eSeal preservation; supervised/accredited trust services for electronic registered delivery.

Source: REGULATION (EU) No 910/2014 OF THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AND OF THE COUNCIL of 23 July 2014 on electronic identification and trust services for electronic transactions in the internal market and repealing Directive 1999/93/EC.

elements.name: Document Management Service
elements.documentation:
A Document Management Service enables the organisation and  categorization of electronic documents in order to store, publish and reuse these documents in multiple contexts. For a differentiation  between ERMS and EDMS visit section 10.3 of Moreq: http://ec.europa.eu/archival-policy/moreq/doc/moreq_en.

The definition of a Record Management Service includes a differentiation towards record management and e-archiving.

elements.name: e-Payment Component
elements.documentation: An e-Payment Component encapsulates the functionalities for execution or electronic payments.

elements.name: Metadata Management Service
elements.documentation:
A Metadata Management Service enables the creation, storage, categorisation and retrieval of metadata. [DAMA]

Source: http://www.dama.org/

elements.name: Configuration and Cartography Service Component
elements.documentation: A Configuration and Cartography Service Component encapsulates the functionalities for documenting the configuration and architecture of solutions.

elements.name: Lifecycle Management Service
elements.documentation: A Lifecycle Management Service supports the governance of services throughout their lifecycle. [SOA Backplane Reference Model of Gartner]

elements.name: e-Seal Verification and Validation Service
elements.documentation:
An e-Seal Verification and Validation Service is used for the verification of documents that are signed electronically.

According to the eIDAS Regulation, an ‘electronic seal’ means data in electronic form, which is attached to or logically associated with other data in electronic form to ensure the latter’s origin and integrity. The ‘creator of a seal’ is a legal person who creates an electronic seal.

Source: REGULATION (EU) No 910/2014 OF THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AND OF THE COUNCIL of 23 July 2014 on electronic identification and trust services for electronic transactions in the internal market and repealing Directive 1999/93/EC.

elements.name: Collaboration Component
elements.documentation: A Collaboration Component encapsulates the functionalities for  transmission of text and broadcasting of audio and video content.

elements.name: Trust Registry Component
elements.documentation:
A Trust Registry Component enables the discovery of essential information about e.g. supervised/accredited  trust service providers issuing certificates for electronic signatures, for electronic seals or for website authentication; supervised/accredited  trust services for eSignature, eSeal or TimeStamp creation and validation; supervised/accredited  trust services for eSignature  or eSeal preservation; supervised/accredited trust services for electronic registered delivery.

Source: REGULATION (EU) No 910/2014 OF THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AND OF THE COUNCIL of 23 July 2014 on electronic identification and trust services for electronic transactions in the internal market and repealing Directive 1999/93/EC.

elements.name: Messaging Service
elements.documentation: A Messaging Service enables real-time transmission of text over the internet.

elements.name: Administration Component
elements.documentation: An Administration Component encapsulates the functionalities for the administration, monitoring and lifecycle management of services. [SOA Backplane Reference Model of Gartner]

elements.name: e-Seal Creation Service
elements.documentation:
An e-Seal Creation Service is used to sign data in electronic form on behalf of a legal person.  

According to the eIDAS Regulation, an ‘electronic seal’ means data in electronic form, which is attached to or logically associated with other data in electronic form to ensure the latter’s origin and integrity. The ‘creator of a seal’ is a legal person who creates an electronic seal.

Source: REGULATION (EU) No 910/2014 OF THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AND OF THE COUNCIL of 23 July 2014 on electronic identification and trust services for electronic transactions in the internal market and repealing Directive 1999/93/EC.

elements.name: Service Registration Service
elements.documentation: A Service Registration Service provides a mechanism to register the system service within a catalogue to be discovered by other services.

elements.name: Identity Mangement Component
Service Registry Component
elements.documentation: A Service Registry Component encapsulates the service registration functionality.

elements.name: Forms Management Service
elements.documentation: A Forms Management Service enables the dynamic creation, distribution and analysis of forms and online surveys.

elements.name: Identity Management Service
Data Exchange Component
elements.documentation: A Data Exchange Component encapsulates the functionalities for secure data exchange.

elements.name: Registered Electronic Delivery Service
elements.documentation:
According to the eIDAS Regulation, an Electronic Registered Delivery Service is a service that makes it possible to transmit data between third parties by electronic means and provides evidence relating to the handling of the transmitted data, including proof of sending and receiving the data, and that protects transmitted data against the risk of loss, theft, damage or any unauthorised alterations;

Source: REGULATION (EU) No 910/2014 OF THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AND OF THE COUNCIL of 23 July 2014 on electronic identification and trust services for electronic transactions in the internal market and repealing Directive 1999/93/EC.

elements.name: Record Management Component
elements.documentation: A Record Management Component encapsulates the functionalities for the classification, storage, archiving, and destruction of electronic records.

elements.name: Audiovisual Service
elements.documentation: An Audiovisual Service enables the broadcast of audio and video content over the internet or satellite.

elements.name: Partner Management Component
elements.documentation: A Partner Management Component encapsulates the functionalities for managing the consumers of services. [SOA Backplane Reference Model of Gartner]

elements.name: Configuration and Cartography Service
elements.documentation: A Configuration and Cartography Service allows the documentation of solution, including its configuration and architecture.

elements.name: e-Payment Service
elements.documentation:
An e-Payment Service enables the execution of payment transactions where the consent of the payer to execute a payment transaction is given by means of any telecommunication, digital or IT device. [Directive 2007/64/EC]

Source:
http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:32007L0064:EN:NOT

elements.name: e-Signature Creation Service
elements.documentation:
An e-Signature Creation Service is used by a natural person to sign data in electronic form.  

According to the eIDAS Regulation, an ‘electronic signature’ means data in electronic form which is attached to or logically associated with other data in electronic form and which is used by the signatory to sign.

Source: REGULATION (EU) No 910/2014 OF THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AND OF THE COUNCIL of 23 July 2014 on electronic identification and trust services for electronic transactions in the internal market and repealing Directive 1999/93/EC.

elements.name: Trust Service Provisioning Component
elements.documentation:
A Trust Service Provisioning Component is a component that provides trust services. 

According to the eIDAS Regulation, a ‘trust service’ means an electronic service normally provided for remuneration which consists of:
(a) the creation, verification, and validation of electronic signatures, electronic seals or electronic time stamps, electronic registered delivery services and certificates related to those services, or
(b) te creation, verification and validation of certificates for website authentication; or
(c) the preservation of electronic signatures, seals or certificates related to those services.

Source: REGULATION (EU) No 910/2014 OF THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AND OF THE COUNCIL of 23 July 2014 on electronic identification and trust services for electronic transactions in the internal market and repealing Directive 1999/93/EC.

elements.name: Forms Management Component
elements.documentation: A Forms Management Component encapsulates the functionalities for the management of forms.

elements.name: Record Management Service
elements.documentation:
A Records Management Service enables the classification, storage, access, and disposal of the records of an organization from the time they are captured (e.g. creation of an internal document or reception of an external document) up to their eventual disposal. Electronic records are document(s) in digital format produced or received by a person or organisation in the course of business, and retained by that person or organisation.

The definition of a Record Management Service includes a differentiation towards record management and e-archiving.

Source: Based on the archival policy of the European Commission
http://ec.europa.eu/archival-policy/moreq/doc/moreq_en.pdf

elements.name: Metadata Management Component
elements.documentation: A Metadata Management Component encapsulates the functionalities for the management of metadata.

elements.name: Data Publication Service
elements.documentation: A Data Publication Service makes data available to other services or users.

elements.name: e-Seal Preservation Service
elements.documentation:
An e-Seal Preservation Service is used for extending the trustworthiness of the qualified electronic signature beyond the technological validity period.

According to the eIDAS Regulation, an ‘electronic seal’ means data in electronic form, which is attached to or logically associated with other data in electronic form to ensure the latter’s origin and integrity. The ‘creator of a seal’ is a legal person who creates an electronic seal.

Source: REGULATION (EU) No 910/2014 OF THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AND OF THE COUNCIL of 23 July 2014 on electronic identification and trust services for electronic transactions in the internal market and repealing Directive 1999/93/EC.

elements.name: e-Signature Verification and Validation Service
elements.documentation:
An e-Signature Verification and Validation Service is used for the verification of documents that are signed electronically.

According to the eIDAS Regulation, an ‘electronic signature’ means data in electronic form which is attached to or logically associated with other data in electronic form and which is used by the signatory to sign.
According to the eIDAS Regulation, ‘validation’ means the process of verifying and confirming that an electronic signature or a seal is valid.

Source: REGULATION (EU) No 910/2014 OF THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AND OF THE COUNCIL of 23 July 2014 on electronic identification and trust services for electronic transactions in the internal market and repealing Directive 1999/93/EC.

elements.name: e-Timestamp Verification and Validation Service
elements.documentation:
An e-Timestamp Verification and Validation Service is used for the verification of timestamps used for establishing evidence that a give piece of data existed at a given point in time.

According to the eIDAS Regulation, ‘electronic time stamp’ means data in electronic form which binds other data in electronic form to a particular time establishing evidence that the latter data existed at that time.

Source: REGULATION (EU) No 910/2014 OF THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AND OF THE COUNCIL of 23 July 2014 on electronic identification and trust services for electronic transactions in the internal market and repealing Directive 1999/93/EC.

elements.name: e-Signature Preservation Service
elements.documentation:
An e-Signature Preservation Service is used for extending the trustworthiness of the qualified electronic signature beyond the technological validity period.

According to the eIDAS Regulation, an ‘electronic signature’ means data in electronic form which is attached to or logically associated with other data in electronic form and which is used by the signatory to sign.

Source: REGULATION (EU) No 910/2014 OF THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AND OF THE COUNCIL of 23 July 2014 on electronic identification and trust services for electronic transactions in the internal market and repealing Directive 1999/93/EC.

elements.name: Content Management Service
elements.documentation:
A Content Management Service enables the organisation and categorisation of information resources so that they can be stored, published and reused in multiple contexts. [DAMA]

Source:  http://www.dama.org/

elements.name: Content Management Component
elements.documentation: A Content Management Component encapsulates the functionalities for the organisation and categorization of information resources.

elements.name: e-Archiving Component
elements.documentation: An e-Archiving Component encapsulates the functionalities for electronic archiving of documents.

elements.name: Partner Management Service
elements.documentation: A Partner Management Service enables the management of the consumers of the services offered by the different components (i.e. the Partners) to ensure scalability. It enables the management of IES' interoperability agreements. [SOA Backplane Reference Model of Gartner]

elements.name: Data Exchange Service
elements.documentation:
A Data Exchange Service enables the secure exchange of messages, records, forms and other kinds of data between different ICT systems. This includes data routing, except endpoint discovery. [European Interoperability Framework]

Source: 
http://ec.europa.eu/isa/documents/isa_annex_ii_eif_en.pdf

elements.name: e-Timestamp Creation Service
elements.documentation:
An e-Timestamp Creation Service is used for the verification of timestamps used for establishing evidence that a give piece of data existed at a given point in time.

According to the eIDAS Regulation, ‘electronic time stamp’ means data in electronic form which binds other data in electronic form to a particular time establishing evidence that the latter data existed at that time.

Source: REGULATION (EU) No 910/2014 OF THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AND OF THE COUNCIL of 23 July 2014 on electronic identification and trust services for electronic transactions in the internal market and repealing Directive 1999/93/EC.

elements.name: e-Archiving Service
elements.documentation:
An e-Archiving Service enables the permanent or long-term storage of selected (by an authority) electronic documents or information for preservation purposes like their enduring research value and memory aid. 

The EIRA differentiates between document management, record management and e-archiving as follows:
- Document management is primarily about day-to-day use of electronic documents (create/update/delete/versioning) within the operational environment.
- Record management is primarily about ensuring that information (e.g. in form of an electronic document or database record) is available for business and legal purposes (e.g. to proof and track the handling of contracts). If an electronic document or information is becoming a record (an authority declares it as a record) that electronic document or information needs to be handled by the record management service (based on specific business or legal reasons (e.g. contract negotiation)).
- e-Archiving is primarily about storing records which have been selected (by an authority) for permanent or long-term preservation due to their enduring research value and as a memory aid. An electronic document or information which a) is managed by the document management service or the record management service and b) is no longer needed for business or legal purposes or day-to-day activities, and c) still has value for research purposes or as a memory aid, the electronic document should be managed by the e-archiving service".

elements.name: Data Publication Component
elements.documentation: A Data Publication Component encapsulates the functionalities for data publication services.

elements.name: Machine Translation Component
elements.documentation: A Machine Translation Component encapsulates the machine translation functionalities exposed through the Machine Translation Service.

elements.name: Digital Service Infrastructure
elements.documentation:
A Digital Service Infrastructure is a collection of cross-sectorial infrastructure services and components. They are decoupled from the business which a specific interoperable solution implements. They can be re-used with no or very minor changes by other interoperable solutions or in different policy contexts. [CEF]

Source: http://ec.europa.eu/digital-agenda/en/connecting-europe-facility

elements.name: Machine Translation Service
elements.documentation: A Machine Translation Service enables the automatic translation of data in form of plain text from one EU language to another EU language (or to a set of other EU languages).

elements.name: Administration and Monitoring Service
elements.documentation: An Administration and Monitoring Service enables the administration and monitoring of services offered by the different components. [SOA Backplane Reference Model of Gartner]

elements.name: Test Report
elements.documentation: A Test Report documents the results of verifying the behaviour of one or more test item(s) or system(s) under test. It is making a conformance or interoperability assessment.

elements.name: Data Validation Component
elements.documentation: A Data Validation Component encapsulates the data validation functionalities exposed through the Data Validation Service.

elements.name: Access Management Service
elements.documentation: An Access Management Service provides the mechanisms to ensure that only authorized users can access and perform actions on IT resources.

elements.name: Audit  Service
elements.documentation:
An Audit Service provides support for the principle of accountability, that is holding users of a system accountable for their actions within the system, and detection of policy violations. The audit policy defines the elements of an information system which need to be traced,  for example to assure tracability of actions: what, how, when, where and with what.

Inspired by: http://www.opengroup.org/security/das/xdas_int.htm

elements.name: Orchestration Service
elements.documentation:
Orchestration identifies a sets of transactions involving use of other services and functionalities, according to business rules embodied in one or more documented business processes, with the ultimate goal of performing or providing some other value-added function or service.
The Orchestration Service executes all the required transactions and routes the inputs and outputs of processes according to rules described in a standard language (i.e. BPEL). [European Interoperability Framework]

Source:
http://ec.europa.eu/isa/documents/isa_annex_ii_eif_en.pdf

elements.name: Data Transformation Component
elements.documentation: A Data Transformation Component encapsulates the data transformation functionalities exposed through the Data Transformation Service.

elements.name: Operational Procedure
elements.documentation: An Operational Procedure defines the process of operating a solution, how the procedures are implemented and the rules for operating it.

elements.name: Machine to Machine Interface
elements.documentation: A Machine to Machine Interface is a description of a boundary between a system and other systems, usually including the mechanisms by which information is transferred. [DG TAXUD]

elements.name: Data Transformation Service
elements.documentation: A Data Transformation Service converts data. This includes the conversion from one data format to another.

elements.name: Data Validation Service
elements.documentation: A Data Validation Service is used to validate data against predefined semantic and syntactic constraints.

elements.name: Logging Service
elements.documentation: An Logging Service traces all events and user actions impacting a data entity throughout its lifecycle (from its creation to its disposal). It can be used to reproduce a certain state of a data entity at a certain moment in time.

elements.name: Business Process Management Component
elements.documentation: A Business Process Management Component encapsulates the functionalities for the orchestration/choreography of business processes.

elements.name: Application Service
elements.documentation: An Application Service is an externally visible unit of functionality, provided by one or more application components. It is exposed through well-defined interfaces and is meaningful to the environment. A Application Service exposes the functionality of components to their environment. This functionality is accessed through one or more application interfaces.

elements.name: Access Management Component
elements.documentation: An Access Management Component encapsulates the functionalities  to authorize users exposed through the Access Management Service.

elements.name: Test Scenario
elements.documentation: A Test Scenario defines the different test cases which needs to be performed by the Test Service. Each scenario (actual) outcome is validated against the pre-defined expected outcome.

elements.name: Interoperable European Solution
elements.documentation:
An Interoperable European Solution (IES) is a solution, developed by Public Administrations that facilitate the delivery of electronic Public Services and cross-border exchange of information between Public Administrations (or Citizens) in support to the implementation and advancement of EU, national or local Public Policies.

Source: This IES definition was derived from the Trans-European Systems definition.

elements.name: Choreography Service
elements.documentation:
The Choreography Service is  the interplay among groups of services which, in turn, make up a larger, composite service, or which interact across organisational boundaries in order to obtain and process information. [W3C]

Source: http://www.w3.org/TR/ws-cdl-10/

elements.name: Technical Specification
elements.documentation: A Technical Specification is a document describing the functional/technical specifications of a solution.

elements.name: Business Intelligence Component
elements.documentation: A Business Intelligence Component encapsulates the functionalities exposed through the Business Analytics Service.

elements.name: Business Analytics Service
elements.documentation: A Business Analytics Service enables the storage and manipulation of dimensional data models for the analysis of business trends and projections. [DAMA]

elements.name: Human Interface
elements.documentation: A Human Interface is a specific interface between the human users of an IT system and the programs providing screen or printed results. It is frequently regarded as a dedicated set of programs, separate from those which extract and process data. [DG TAXUD]

elements.name: Configuration Management
elements.documentation: A Configuration management is the means of maintaining Interoperable European Solutions to safeguard the performance of these solution. This includes change management, versioning, etc.

elements.name: Test Service
elements.documentation: A Test Service enables the execution of interoperability and conformance testing. A Test Service is realised by one or more Test Components.

elements.name: Business Reporting Service
elements.documentation: A Business Reporting Service provides detailed reports using unified views of enterprise data. [DAMA]

elements.name: Test Component
elements.documentation: A Test Component encapsulates the functionalities for conformance and interoperability testing.

elements.name: Service Discovery Service
elements.documentation: A Service Discovery Service allows the automatic discovery of other services.

elements.name: Audit and Logging Component
elements.documentation: An Audit and Logging Component encapsulates the functionalities for auditing and logging of events.

elements.name: Hosting and Networking Infrastructure Service
elements.documentation: A Hosting and Networking Infrastructure Service is a collection of services for hosting Interoperable European Solutions and provides the necessary networks for operating these solutions.

elements.name: Private Hosting Facility
elements.documentation: A Private Hosting Facility is a Hosting Facility which is owned by or dedicated to one organization (e.g. data centre or private cloud).

elements.name: Hosting Service
elements.documentation: A Hosting  Service is a service provided by a hosting provider. [DIGIT C Infrastructure Services Provision]

elements.name: Hosting Facility
elements.documentation:
A Hosting Facility is usually embodied in a building and the equipment supporting the hosting of Interoperable European Solutions and their components.
[DIGIT C Infrastructure Services Provision]

elements.name: Public Hosting Facility
elements.documentation: A Public Hosting Facility is a Hosting Facility which is owned by a third party and shared between organizations (e.g. cloud services).

elements.name: Networking Service
elements.documentation: A Networking Service is a service provided by a network provider. [DIGIT C Infrastructure Services Provision]

elements.name: Private Network
elements.documentation: A Private Network is a network that is used for the only purpose of realising the physical communication among Interoperable European Solution (e.g. sTESTA), and cannot be accessed by the public.

elements.name: Public Network
elements.documentation: A Public Network is a network that can be accessed by the public (public administrations, businesses and citizens) without specific authorisations. Interoperable European Solutions can rely on Public Networks (e.g. the Internet) to realise the physical communication between nodes.

elements.name: Network
elements.documentation: A Network realises the physical communication layer among nodes participating in an Interoperable European Solution.

relationships.name: responsible for
relationships.documentation: An [Interoperability Organisation Authority] is responsible for [Interoperability Governance]
A [Public Policy Formulation and Implementation Instrument] is associated to [Legal Interoperability Specification]

relationships.name: signs
relationships.documentation: An [Organisation] signs an [Interoperability Agreement]

relationships.name: is influenced by
relationships.documentation: An [Organisational Policy] is influenced by a [Public Policy]

relationships.name: represents
relationships.documentation: A [Representation] represents [Data]

relationships.name: supports
relationships.documentation: An [Interoperable European Solution] supports a [Public Policy]

relationships.name: is signed by
relationships.documentation: An [Interoperability Agreement] is signed by a [Public Service Provider]

relationships.name: is supported by
relationships.documentation: A [Public Service] is supported by an [Interoperable European Solution]

relationships.name: is provided by
relationships.documentation: A [Representation] is provided by a [Machine to Machine Interface]

relationships.name: has its interoperability aspects defined by
relationships.documentation: A [Service Registry Component] has its interoperability aspects defined by a [Technical Interoperability Specification]

relationships.name: documents
relationships.documentation: A [Public Service Catalogue] documents a [Public Service]

relationships.name: is included in
relationships.documentation: A [Public Policy Formulation and Implementation Instrument] is included in a [Legislation Catalogue]

relationships.name: defines the interoperability aspects for
relationships.documentation: A [Technical Interoperability Specification] defines the interoperability aspects for [Service Registry Component] (contents and the registry as a whole).

relationships.name: defines the interoperability aspects for
relationships.documentation: A [Legal Interoperability Specification] defines the interoperability aspects for a [Legislation Catalogue] (contents and the catalogue as a whole).

relationships.name: influences
relationships.documentation: A [Data Policy] influences [Representation]

relationships.name: is source of
relationships.documentation: An [Organisational Interoperability Enabler] is source of a [Business Rule]

relationships.name: implements
relationships.documentation: An [Interoperability Strategy] implements an [Interoperability Framework]

relationships.name: incorporates
relationships.documentation: A [Representation] incorporates a [Data Standard]

relationships.name: influences
relationships.documentation: A [Public Policy Development Enabler] influences a [Public Policy]

relationships.name: is realised by
relationships.documentation: A [Public Policy] is realised by a [Public Policy Formulation and Implementation Instrument]

relationships.name: implements
relationships.documentation: A [Public Service] implements a [Public Policy]

relationships.name: is provided by
relationships.documentation: A [Representation] is provided by a [Human Interface]

relationships.name: acts on behalf of
relationships.documentation: A [Public Service Delivery Agent] acts on behalf of [Public Service Provider]

relationships.name: provides
relationships.documentation: A [Human Interface] provides [Representations] of data.

relationships.name: is influenced by
relationships.documentation: An [Interoperability Strategy] is influenced by [Interoperability Governance]

relationships.name: influences
relationships.documentation: A [Public Policy] influences an [Organisational Policy]

relationships.name: uses
relationships.documentation: A [Public Service Consumer] uses a [Service Delivery Model] to consume a [Public Service]

relationships.name: has
relationships.documentation: [Data] has a [Representation]

relationships.name: is described in
relationships.documentation: An [Organisational Interoperability Specification] is described in an [Interoperability Agreements]

relationships.name: defines the interoperability aspects for
relationships.documentation: An [Organisational Interoperability Specification] defines the interoperability aspects for a [Public Service Catalogue] (contents and the catalogue as a whole).

relationships.name: has its interoperability aspects defined by
relationships.documentation: A [Data Standard Catalogue] has its interoperability aspects defined by a [Semantic Interoperability Specification]

relationships.name: defines the interoperability aspects for
relationships.documentation: A [Semantic Interoperability Specification] defines the interoperability aspects for a [Data Set Catalogue] (contents and the catalogue as a whole).

relationships.name: proposes
relationships.documentation: A [Public Service Provider] proposes a [Service Delivery Model]

relationships.name: has its interoperability aspects defined by
relationships.documentation: A [Data Set Catalogue] has its interoperability aspects defined by a [Semantic Interoperability Specification]

relationships.name: provides
relationships.documentation: A [Machine to Machine Interface Interface] provides [Representations] of data.

relationships.name: offers
relationships.documentation: A [Network] offers a [Networking Service]

relationships.name: is agreed to by
relationships.documentation: An [Interoperability Agreement] is agreed to by a [Citizen]

relationships.name: is described by
relationships.documentation: [Data] is described by a [Data Standard]

relationships.name: is implemented by
relationships.documentation: A [Public Policy] is implemented by a [Public Service]
A [Legal Interoperability Specification] is associated to [Public Policy Formulation and Implement Instrument]

relationships.name: applies to
relationships.documentation: A [Business Rule] applies to [Business Information]

relationships.name: defines the interoperability aspects for
relationships.documentation: A [Semantic Interoperability Specification] defines the interoperability aspects for a [Data Standard Catalogue] (contents and the catalogue as a whole).

relationships.name: is offered by
relationships.documentation: A [Hosting Service] is offered by a [Hosting Facility]

views.name: Semantic view
views.documentation:
The Semantic view models the most important building blocks that should be considered in order to support semantic interoperability of information exchanges between administrations, businesses and citizens.

Narrative: [Business Information] is realised by a [Representation] of [Data] which is described by [Data Standards]. 
[Data] can be grouped in [Data Sets], which can be documented in [Data Set Catalogues]. [Master Data], [Transactional Data],  [Reference Data] and [Descriptive Metadata] are specialisations of [Data]. [Data] is described by [Data Standards]. [Data Standards] have the following specialisations: [Data Model]/[Core Data Model] consisting of among others [Data Entities], [Character Encoding Scheme], [Syntax Encoding Scheme], [Data-level Mapping], [Schema Level Mapping] or [Identifier Scheme]. [Data Standards] can be documented in [Data Standard Catalogues].

[Representation] is influenced by [Data Policies], which are [Organisational Policies], which is in turn are influenced by [Public Policies].

views.name: Legal view
views.documentation:
The Legal view models the most important public policy development enablers and implementation instruments that shall be considered in order to support legal interoperability.

Narrative: A [Public Policy] is the outcome of a specific [Public Policy Cycle] that aims at addressing the needs of a group of stakeholders. The Public Policy Cycle consists of the following subsequent steps: [Definition of Public Policy Objectives], [Formulation of Public Policy Scenarios], [Impact Assessment], [Public Policy Implementation], and [Public Policy Evaluation].

The [Public Policy] is developed taking into account [Public Policy Development Enablers], such as a [Public Policy Development Approach] or a [Public Policy Development Mandate]. The policy is formulated and implemented with the help of [Public Policy Formulation and Implementation Instruments] such as [Legal Requirements or Constraints] in the form of either [Binding Instruments] or [Non-Binding Instruments], or [Operational Enablers], such as [Financial Resources] or [Implementing Guidelines].

views.name: EIRA high-level overview
views.documentation:
The EIRA high-level overview, visualises the focal architecture building blocks of each view. It provides an introductory overview of the most important EIRA ABBs. It aligns the EIRA with the service delivery model described within the Interoperability Maturity Model (IMM) and the EIF conceptual model for public services.

The ABBs included in the high-level overview represent the points that link the EIRA’s views enabling traceability between their different building blocks. As such they should be considered as key elements of any interoperability solution, reference architecture or solution architecture template. They are not necessarily mandatory but should always be considered by a user of the EIRA when executing one of its use cases.

Narrative: A [Public Policy] is implemented by a [Public Service] which can be an aggregation of other [Public Services] . The [Public Service] is realised by [Business Capabilities] describing key functions supporting the service. A [Business Capability] can contain [Business Information Exchanges] which describe interactions between public administrations, businesses, and citizens. A [Business Information Exchange] accesses [Business Information] realized by a [Representation] of [Data]. The representation is influenced by a [Data Policy], which may in turn be influenced by a [Public Policy]. An [Interoperable European Solution] supports one or more [Public Services] and lets users access it via [Machine to Machine Interfaces] and/or [Human Interfaces]. An [Interoperable European Solution] exposes [Application Services] via its [Machine to Machine Interfaces] and Human Interfaces]. It makes use of [Orchestration Services] and [Choreography Services]. The [Interoperable European Solution] uses [Digital Service Infrastructure] and [Hosting and Networking Infrastructure Service]. It can also use other [Interoperable European Solutions].

views.name: Organisational view
views.documentation:
The Organisational view models the most important building blocks that shall be considered in order to support organisational interoperability among providers and users of a public service.

Narrative: [Organisations] in the role of [Public Service Providers] supply [Public Services] to [Citizens] and [Businesses] and/or [Public Administrations] which have the role of [Public Service Consumer]. The [Public Service] is delivered according to its [Service Delivery Model].  [Public Services] are documented in [Public Service Catalogues] that can be used among others for service portfolio management.
[Public Service Providers] can delegate the delivery of [Public Services] to [Public Service Delivery Agents] who will act on behalf of [Public Service Providers].
[Public Service Providers] can sign an [Interoperability Provider Agreement] to agree on how to deliver a [Public Service] to its users. The delivery of these public services is realised through [Business Capabilities] using [Business Information Exchanges] and [Business Information]. [Business Information] is instance oriented and is subject to [Business Rules] originating from [Organisational Enablers] like [Organisational Structures], [Organisational Procedures], [Organisational Policies] or the [Organisational Skills] of the [Organisations] involved.
The [Interoperability Organisational Authority] is responsible for [Interoperability Governance] which influences the [Interoperability Strategy]. The [Interoperability Strategy] implements the [Interoperability Framework].  
[Interoperability Skills] are a specific form of [Organisational Skills] that allows the organisation to excel in interoperability.

views.name: Interoperability specification underpinning view
views.documentation:
The interoperability specification underpinning view provides a metamodel of architecture building blocks from the different views, and depicts them as a taxonomy of interoperability specifications. Each EIRA view has architecture building blocks that support interoperability.

Each view’s interoperability specifications serve to define the interoperability aspects of catalogues and registries, addressing both their contents and the respective catalogue or registry as a whole. Given the linked nature of the EIRA’s views, the interoperability specifications from all views can be considered to affect each individual catalogue or registry. However, the focus in each case is kept within the specific view to best capture the level of detail that each view’s specifications deal with.

Narrative: An [Interoperability Specification] is a [Specification]. An [Interoperability Specification] can depend on other [Interoperability Specifications]. It exists at the four levels of interoperability defined in the European Interoperability Framework: 
•	At the legal level a [Legal Interoperability Specification] is associated to [Public Policy Formulation and Implement Instrument] and/or documented in [Legislation Catalogue].
•	At the organisational level an [Organisational Interoperability Specification] is described with the help of [Interoperability Agreements] and/or documented in [Public Service Catalogue].
•	At the semantic level a [Semantic Interoperability Specification] has the form of [Data Set Catalogue] and/or [Data Standards Catalogue].
•	At the technical level a [Technical Interoperability Specification] is a [Technical Specification] describing aspects of the underlying system. The [Service Registry Component] provides a mechanism to register technical services within a catalogue to be discovered by others.
